channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: House Cancels Contempt Vote As Clintons Agree to Testify on Epstein
item.description: Bill and Hillary Clinton agreed to be deposed this month by an investigative panel but requested that it be in public, a request that the Republican chairman ignored.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:description: Former President Bill Clinton and former Senator Hillary Clinton at President Trump’s inauguration in 2025.

item.title: Jeffrey Epstein’s Trust Reveals Beneficiaries of His Fortune
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein wanted most of his money to go to his girlfriend. Mr. Epstein’s brother and a Harvard math professor were also named beneficiaries.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:description: It’s unclear how much any of the beneficiaries to Jeffrey Epstein’s estate will receive. Its value has dropped significantly since his death, owing to payment of taxes, legal fees and settlements to victims of his sexual abuse.

item.title: Catherine O’Hara, Star of ‘Best in Show,’ Honored in Westminster Tribute
item.description: Fans remembered the actress, who died last week at 71, for her role as the doting owner of a Norwich terrier destined for glory in the movie, a sendup of dog show culture.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Doane Gregory/Online USA, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara as Cookie Fleck, a Florida dog lover with a past, in Christopher Guest’s “Best in Show.” Her hapless husband, Gerry (Eugene Levy), rose to the occasion in the film’s fictional dog show.

item.title: Trump, Changing Course, Throws Harvard Deal Talks Into Chaos
item.description: In the latest example of his mercurial negotiating style, President Trump went from dropping his ask for a $200 million fine to demanding $1 billion from the university.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender, Alan Blinder, Mark Arsenault and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump appeared to once again threaten to cut off Harvard from future research funding, which is the lifeblood of major research universities.

item.title: Trump Repeats Call to ‘Nationalize’ Elections, as White House Walks It Back
item.description: President Trump’s extraordinary comments were the latest iteration of his unsubstantiated claims that U.S. elections are rigged as Republicans face potentially big losses next year.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green, Michael Gold and Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Nick Hagen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign directs voters in Dearborn, Mich., in November 2024.

item.title: Trump Scolds CNN’s Kaitlan Collins for ‘Not Smiling’
item.description: Testy remarks from a president who has frequently singled out female journalists for criticism and personal attacks.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:description: CNN’s Kaitlan Collins, center, asks President Donald Trump a question in the Oval Office in November.

item.title: Renee Good’s Brothers Call on Congress to Rein In Immigration Crackdown
item.description: At a forum on Capitol Hill held by congressional Democrats, the brothers of the 37-year-old American citizen fatally shot by an ICE agent said immigration enforcement tactics must be dialed back.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Brothers of Renee Good, Luke Ganger, left, and Brent Ganger, during a public forum at the Capitol in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Don Lemon Takes Stage at NYC Event After Arrest Over Minnesota Protest
item.description: The anchorman, who was arrested over a protest in Minnesota, told an audience in Manhattan, “I’m not going to let them turn me around,” and sang lines from a civil rights era freedom song.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Southall and Davaughnia Wilson
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Don Lemon, the former CNN anchor, was arrested last week after he covered a protest in January at a church in Minnesota.

item.title: South Korea Questions Cram School Culture and Childhood Stress
item.description: Academic pressure has become so intense that even preschoolers are taking private extracurricular classes, raising worries about children’s rights.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim and Jean Chung
item.media:description: Seoul has “Therapy Zone” boxes, soundproof spaces where students can study, or vent, in the evenings after school.

item.title: How 2026 Winter Olympics Security Is Preparing For The Opening Ceremony
item.description: Thousands of police and security officers will work during the Milan-Cortina Games’ opening ceremony. The involvement of some U.S. ICE personnel has stirred opposition.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Italian carabinieri in Milan on Sunday. The city is hosting the Winter Olympics this month.

item.title: ‘Neoroyalism’ and What It Says About Trump
item.description: Experts are reaching to divine the president’s approach to global policy and economics, with one theory seeing antecedents in centuries-old dynastic rule.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman gave President Trump a warm and opulent welcome in Saudi Arabia last year.

item.title: Plastic Surgeons’ Group Advises Delaying Gender-Affirming Procedures Until Age 19
item.description: The organization’s latest guidance is a departure from the prevailing views of several other major medical organizations.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:description: Between 2016 and 2020, about 3,700 patients 18 years old and younger have undergone gender transition surgery, mostly for breast removal, according to a JAMA study.

item.title: Woman Wins Malpractice Suit Over Gender Surgery as a Minor
item.description: In a legal first, a jury in New York awarded $2 million to a patient who said that doctors had deviated from accepted medical standards.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.category: World Professional Association for Transgender Health
item.media:description: Recent studies have suggested that between 5 and 10 percent of young people who had undergone gender-affirming care later decided to detransition.

item.title: Ruptures in China’s Leadership Could Be Due to Paranoia and Power Plays
item.description: U.S. intelligence analysts say that Xi Jinping, China’s leader, has a remarkable level of fear. He has carried out mass purges, and surprised many by removing his top general.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Xi Jinping during a military parade in Tiananmen Square in Beijing last year.

item.title: Savannah Guthrie to Skip Olympics as Search for Mother, Nancy Guthrie, Yields Few Clues
item.description: The ‘Today’ anchor withdrew from NBC’s coverage of the Winter Games in Italy as investigators acknowledged they had few answers about who may have taken her mother, Nancy Guthrie, 84, from her home.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Reis Thebault
item.media:description: Savannah Guthrie, right, with her mother, Nancy, in 2019.

item.title: What to Know About the Disappearance of Savannah Guthrie’s Mom, Nancy
item.description: Nancy Guthrie, 84, the “Today” show host’s mother, was last seen on Saturday night, the authorities said. The disappearance is being investigated as a crime.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers outside the home of Nancy Guthrie near Tucson, Ariz., on Monday.

item.title: Colleges See Major Racial Shifts in Student Enrollment
item.description: An analysis finds that flagship state universities, as well as less selective colleges, had major increases in Black and Hispanic students following a ban on race-conscious admissions.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul

item.title: Racial Debate Rattles Texas Democratic Primary for Senate
item.description: State Representative James Talarico used the word “mediocre” in connection with a former House member who is Black. The controversy has repercussions for a key contest.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Texas State Representative James Talarico at a town hall in New Braunfels, Texas, last month.

item.title: Walmart Joins Tech Giants With $1 Trillion Market Valuation
item.description: The company’s rapid e-commerce growth and push into automation and artificial intelligence propelled its stock into the trillion-dollar club.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone

item.title: Everyone Is Missing the Point About the ‘Melania’ Movie
item.description: It’s not really a movie at all. It’s a marketing deck.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: Melania Trump at the screening of “Melania” at the Kennedy Center last week.

item.title: William Stevenson, Jill Biden’s Ex-Husband, Is Accused of Killing His Current Wife
item.description: William Stevenson was arrested after being indicted on charges of first-degree murder in the death of his wife in December. He was married to Dr. Biden in the 1970s.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz

item.title: Will Newsom Be the Democrats’ Next Mistake?
item.description: The California governor’s record is exactly what Republicans want to run against.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens

item.title: In Counting the Dead in Iran, a Picture of Ferocity
item.description: The high number of dead and wounded demonstrates the depths of the regime’s fears.
item.dc:creator: Scott Anderson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Tyler Robinson’s Lawyers Press to Remove Prosecutors From Kirk Murder Case
item.description: Mr. Robinson’s lawyers argue that the entire prosecution team has a conflict of interest because one prosecutor’s daughter was present when Charlie Kirk was killed.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:description: Chad Grunander, a deputy Utah County attorney, testifying during a hearing in the Fourth District Court in Provo, Utah, on Tuesday.

item.title: Mamdani Seeks New Mission for Pro-Business Agency: Fighting for Workers
item.description: According to a Jan. 2 memo obtained by The New York Times, Mayor Zohran Mamdani wants to remake the Economic Development Corporation to address affordability and workers’ rights.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag and Dana Rubinstein
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: In December, Zohran Mamdani named Julie Su, right, as the city’s first ever deputy mayor for economic justice.

item.title: Virginia Oliver, Maine’s ‘Lobster Lady’ and Folk Hero, Dies at 105
item.description: She fished off the New England coast for more than 80 years, and intended to continue until she died. “It’s not hard work for me,” she said at 101.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald
item.media:description: Ms. Oliver in 2021, when she was 101. “She represented that no-nonsense Mainer who just got up every day and did what they had to do,” said Barbara Walsh, the author of a children’s book about Mrs. Oliver.

item.title: Backed by Mamdani, D.S.A. Candidate Wins Election for Mayor’s Old Seat
item.description: Diana Moreno will serve the remainder of Mayor Zohran Mamdani’s term in the New York State Assembly in one of four special legislative elections decided on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Diana Moreno, who was born in Ecuador, said that she would prioritize legislation to stop localities from collaborating with federal immigration agents.
